texts.text: Dek: How we let you search millions of Twitter bios
To build this story, we tackled two problems. First, we organized millions users’ profiles into a special format built for searching. Second, we found meaning.

We examined the 18,686,752 Twitter users who followed Trump or Clinton at the time of our analysis. Of those, 7,972,079 users wrote bios: 4,232,803 Clinton followers and 5,078,544 Trump followers. There’s an overlap of 1,339,268 users with bios who follow both Clinton and Trump.

To find meaning — and the terms we highlighted in the text of our story — we used the economics concept of an
(number of Clinton followers who use the term ÷ total number of Clinton followers) ÷ (number of Trump followers who use the term ÷ total number of Trump followers)
When this formula gives a high result, we say a term “over-indexes” among Clinton followers. We also examined terms that over-index among Trump followers.

A term can over-index among Clinton followers even the number of Trump followers who use it is higher. That’s because the total number of Trump followers is greater than the total number of Clinton followers.
The sentence below each Venn diagram describes this over-indexing: The followers who over-index are
more likely to use a term than the followers who under-index.
